summary: Everyone is so obsessed with dragongs, and the white walkers, nobody even takes the time to notice how many cool knives I have.

blog.name: ghettootaku
blog.title: gey
blog.description: the-great-azoo.tumblr.com

body:
I actually ship Petyr/Sansa

Not as much like lovers, but more like business partners so to speak. And I know it’s creepy as it is, but I think they could have really helped each others character development and storyline going in to this last season. I would have loved to see how it worked out in the very end. If Sansa was a little bit more and Petyr was a little bit less, I think they would have had a great power dynamic n the end.

blog.name: secretlyatargaryen
blog.title: Worms are crawling in and out of Rhaegar's ass
blog.description: Jenny. This blog consists mainly of Game of Thrones/A Song of Ice and Fire, with particular focus on Tyrion, but also among my favorites are Sansa, Cersei, Arya, and Brienne. I also occasionally post about video games or books or whatever else I find interesting.

summary: There are a lot of reasons Sansa should not have been forced into the marriage with Tyrion, but she does have ableist thoughts...
body:
There are a lot of reasons Sansa should not have been forced into the marriage with Tyrion, but she does have ableist thoughts about him, and Tyrion picks up on it because surprise! Disabled people know when able bodied people are looking at us like we’re disgusting! We recognize those looks, because we’ve had to deal with them our whole lives.

Sansa is a lot nicer to Tyrion than most people are, but Tyrion still recognizes that look, the look he talked about in AGOT:

“Be certain that you tell her who I am, and warn her of what I am.“ Jyck had not always troubled to do that. There was a look the girls got in their eyes sometimes when they first beheld the lordling they’d been hired to pleasure … a look that Tyrion Lannister did not ever care to see again.

Disabled people learn pretty early in their lives what that look is like and how to watch out for it and guard yourself against it. And Tyrion is also an abuse victim who has had to learn how to recognize when people view him as lesser because of his disability because being viewed as lesser means you can be abused. A lot of the parts of Tyrion’s personality are coping mechanisms for this: he’s always the first person in the room to make an ableist joke so that other people can’t hurt him with it, he shoves his difference in other people’s faces.

We don’t get Tyrion’s POV on their wedding night but we do get Sansa’s thoughts. We KNOW she is ableist.

She was mortified. It was not supposed to be this way. She had dreamed of her wedding a thousand times, and always she had pictured how her betrothed would stand behind her tall and strong, sweep the cloak of his protection over her shoulders, and tenderly kiss her cheek as he leaned forward to fasten the clasp.

[…]

He is so ugly, Sansa thought when his face was close to hers. He is even uglier than the Hound. 

[…]

She stared at the stunted legs, the swollen brutish brow, the green eye and the black one, the raw stump of his nose and crooked pink scar, the coarse tangle of black and gold hair that passed for his beard. Even his manhood was ugly, thick and veined, with a bulbous purple head. This is not right, this is not fair, how have I sinned that the gods would do this to me, how?

Sansa is right about that last part. It’s not right and it’s not fair, but it is those things because she’s a child and a hostage who is being abused, not because of Tyrion’s appearance or because he’s not tall enough to cloak her. The cloaking is also a way that ableism is ingrained in the very culture, reinforcing patriarchal norms. This also helps oppress women because it distracts Sansa from the real unfairness of the situation. If only her husband was big and strong, then everything would be okay. Tyrion has some of the same thoughts. If only he were big and strong, maybe Sansa would love him. This is one of the ways that oppression destroys people, by making them feel as if it’s their fault. Of course, this causes Tyrion to withdraw more into himself.

He is as frightened as I am, Sansa realized. Perhaps that should have made her feel more kindly toward him, but it did not. All she felt was pity, and pity was death to desire.

Tyrion also knows, I think, that Sansa pities him, and while, like I said, this is a lot nicer than the way most people treat him, disabled people have also been trained to watch out for pity and condescension, because those are the things we get when able bodied people don’t actively hate us.

Tyrion also fears being vulnerable - because again, being vulnerable means you can be abused, and Tyrion’s had it drilled into him by Tywin that Lannisters can’t show weakness, and that Tyrion’s own weaknesses make him not a true member of his family - and he’s intensely vulnerable in this scene. Sansa picks up on this too, and recognizes his fear. Despite her own terror and vulnerability, which I think is an amazing feat of empathy on Sansa’s part. Yet, the damage has still been done.

We don’t get Tyrion’s thoughts this chapter but we do get them later:

And their nights together in the great bed were another source of torment. He could no longer bear to sleep naked, as had been his custom. His wife was too well trained ever to say an unkind word, but the revulsion in her eyes whenever she looked on his body was more than he could bear.

[…]

The way she looked at him, her stiffness when she climbed into their bed … when he was with her, never for an instant could he forget who he was, or what he was. No more than she did.

There’s that echo again. Warn her of who I am, and what I am.

Not all of Sansa’s negative looks are ableism, I think. I mean, of course she’s gonna look with revulsion and terror at a naked man in her bed that she’s been forced to marry, especially when she has no idea whether he might decided to hurt her. But ableism is certainly a part of it, and I think that the societal ableism that Sansa has picked up has only increased her fear and terror of Tyrion, which in turn makes her more repulsed by his disabled body because she’s already repulsed by the situation as a whole. Her ableism is…not really her fault, but it’s still there, and for Tyrion it is no less painful or real. And to treat it like Tyrion is just imagining it or just being bitter is incredibly condescending and invalidating to disabled people who have had the experience of being looked at differently because of their disability. You can acknowledge that Sansa is a victim while also acknowledging that Tyrion’s experiences as a disabled man are real and his trauma valid. Both of them deserve that respect and basic humanity. 

And you’re not entitled to revoke your empathy for disabled people just because a disabled person does something bad. Our humanity is not conditional on the things we do, it’s not a card that the able bodied get to give out and take away if they don’t like us. I don’t care what you think of Tyrion, that still does not entitle you to be ableist.

But ableism is certainly a part of it, and I think that the societal ableism that Sansa has picked up has only increased her fear and terror of Tyrion, which in turn makes her more repulsed by his disabled body because she’s already repulsed by the situation as a whole. Her ableism is…not really her fault, but it’s still there, and for Tyrion it is no less painful or real. And to treat it like Tyrion is just imagining it or just being bitter is incredibly condescending and invalidating to disabled people who have had the experience of being looked at differently because of their disability. You can acknowledge that Sansa is a victim while also acknowledging that Tyrion’s experiences as a disabled man are real and his trauma valid. Both of them deserve that respect and basic humanity. 

And you’re not entitled to revoke your empathy for disabled people just because a disabled person does something bad. Our humanity is not conditional on the things we do, it’s not a card that the able bodied get to give out and take away if they don’t like us. I don’t care what you think of Tyrion, that still does not entitle you to be ableist.
trail.content:
There are a lot of reasons Sansa should not have been forced into the marriage with Tyrion, but she does have ableist thoughts about him, and Tyrion picks up on it because surprise! Disabled people know when able bodied people are looking at us like we’re disgusting! We recognize those looks, because we’ve had to deal with them our whole lives.

Sansa is a lot nicer to Tyrion than most people are, but Tyrion still recognizes that look, the look he talked about in AGOT:

“Be certain that you tell her who I am, and warn her of what I am.“ Jyck had not always troubled to do that. There was a look the girls got in their eyes sometimes when they first beheld the lordling they’d been hired to pleasure … a look that Tyrion Lannister did not ever care to see again.

Disabled people learn pretty early in their lives what that look is like and how to watch out for it and guard yourself against it. And Tyrion is also an abuse victim who has had to learn how to recognize when people view him as lesser because of his disability because being viewed as lesser means you can be abused. A lot of the parts of Tyrion’s personality are coping mechanisms for this: he’s always the first person in the room to make an ableist joke so that other people can’t hurt him with it, he shoves his difference in other people’s faces.

We don’t get Tyrion’s POV on their wedding night but we do get Sansa’s thoughts. We KNOW she is ableist.

She was mortified. It was not supposed to be this way. She had dreamed of her wedding a thousand times, and always she had pictured how her betrothed would stand behind her tall and strong, sweep the cloak of his protection over her shoulders, and tenderly kiss her cheek as he leaned forward to fasten the clasp.

[…]

He is so ugly, Sansa thought when his face was close to hers. He is even uglier than the Hound. 

[…]

She stared at the stunted legs, the swollen brutish brow, the green eye and the black one, the raw stump of his nose and crooked pink scar, the coarse tangle of black and gold hair that passed for his beard. Even his manhood was ugly, thick and veined, with a bulbous purple head. This is not right, this is not fair, how have I sinned that the gods would do this to me, how?

Sansa is right about that last part. It’s not right and it’s not fair, but it is those things because she’s a child and a hostage who is being abused, not because of Tyrion’s appearance or because he’s not tall enough to cloak her. The cloaking is also a way that ableism is ingrained in the very culture, reinforcing patriarchal norms. This also helps oppress women because it distracts Sansa from the real unfairness of the situation. If only her husband was big and strong, then everything would be okay. Tyrion has some of the same thoughts. If only he were big and strong, maybe Sansa would love him. This is one of the ways that oppression destroys people, by making them feel as if it’s their fault. Of course, this causes Tyrion to withdraw more into himself.

He is as frightened as I am, Sansa realized. Perhaps that should have made her feel more kindly toward him, but it did not. All she felt was pity, and pity was death to desire.

Tyrion also knows, I think, that Sansa pities him, and while, like I said, this is a lot nicer than the way most people treat him, disabled people have also been trained to watch out for pity and condescension, because those are the things we get when able bodied people don’t actively hate us.

Tyrion also fears being vulnerable - because again, being vulnerable means you can be abused, and Tyrion’s had it drilled into him by Tywin that Lannisters can’t show weakness, and that Tyrion’s own weaknesses make him not a true member of his family - and he’s intensely vulnerable in this scene. Sansa picks up on this too, and recognizes his fear. Despite her own terror and vulnerability, which I think is an amazing feat of empathy on Sansa’s part. Yet, the damage has still been done.

We don’t get Tyrion’s thoughts this chapter but we do get them later:

And their nights together in the great bed were another source of torment. He could no longer bear to sleep naked, as had been his custom. His wife was too well trained ever to say an unkind word, but the revulsion in her eyes whenever she looked on his body was more than he could bear.

[…]

The way she looked at him, her stiffness when she climbed into their bed … when he was with her, never for an instant could he forget who he was, or what he was. No more than she did.

There’s that echo again. Warn her of who I am, and what I am.

Not all of Sansa’s negative looks are ableism, I think. I mean, of course she’s gonna look with revulsion and terror at a naked man in her bed that she’s been forced to marry, especially when she has no idea whether he might decided to hurt her. But ableism is certainly a part of it, and I think that the societal ableism that Sansa has picked up has only increased her fear and terror of Tyrion, which in turn makes her more repulsed by his disabled body because she’s already repulsed by the situation as a whole. Her ableism is…not really her fault, but it’s still there, and for Tyrion it is no less painful or real. And to treat it like Tyrion is just imagining it or just being bitter is incredibly condescending and invalidating to disabled people who have had the experience of being looked at differently because of their disability. You can acknowledge that Sansa is a victim while also acknowledging that Tyrion’s experiences as a disabled man are real and his trauma valid. Both of them deserve that respect and basic humanity. 

And you’re not entitled to revoke your empathy for disabled people just because a disabled person does something bad. Our humanity is not conditional on the things we do, it’s not a card that the able bodied get to give out and take away if they don’t like us. I don’t care what you think of Tyrion, that still does not entitle you to be ableist.

title: It's Only a Paper Moon
body:
read it on the AO3 at https://ift.tt/2O6hOdQ

by DaydreamingSophia

1940s-1950s AU

In New York City, cabs and cars fly through the streets like pixies searching for hiding lovers. The War has ended and new life of luxury and endless possibilities infects those who find themselves in the year 1949. We have a painter, Sansa Stark who through her friend Margaery, strikes up a commission for a portrait of the world’s current Heavyweight Champion, The Hound.

Words: 6240, Chapters: 1/?, Language: English

  • Fandoms: A Song of Ice and Fire - George R. R. Martin, Game of Thrones (TV)
  • Rating: Explicit
  • Warnings: No Archive Warnings Apply
  • Categories: F/M
  • Characters: Sansa Stark, Sandor Clegane, Margaery Tyrell, Bronn (ASoIaF), Arya Stark, Catelyn Tully Stark, Harry “The Bastard of Bracken” Rivers, Ned Stark
  • Relationships: Sandor Clegane/Sansa Stark, Sandor Clegane & Sansa Stark
  • Additional Tags: Post-World War II, 1940s, Alternate Universe, Painting, Boxing, New York City, Slow Burn, Smutt, POV Sansa Stark, Eventual Sandor Clegane/Sansa Stark, Modern Era


read it on the AO3 at https://ift.tt/2O6hOdQ

blog.name: incorrect-got-quotes
blog.title: Dead, almost like my interest in the show
blog.description: I post quotes when I feel like it. Mostly nowadays I don’t.If you want to use one of the quotes as a story or drawing prompt, I'm fine with that, as long as you credit me in your story or art. Also, tag any drawings under #oberyn’s saucy art. Yes, I am in fact Oberyn Martell. For those on mobile, here is my ship list: https://incorrect-got-quotes.tumblr.com/list-of-ships Main: garnetislovegarnetislife. SUBMISSION BOX IS (MOST LIKELY) PERMANENTLY CLOSED!

summary:
Myrcella: Maybe we should stop. This is Sansa's room. And she’s right downstairs.
Arya: Do you remember the Independence Day...
body:
Myrcella: Maybe we should stop. This is Sansa’s room. And she’s right downstairs.

Arya: Do you remember the Independence Day party I had at my house last year when Sansa and Margaery had just came out as dating?

Myrcella: Yeah..?

Arya: Do you remember how I went upstairs to get you a blanket from my room, and when I came back down, I was grumpy and blanket-less?

Myrcella: Yeah…

Arya: Yeah. This is revenge sex.

Myrcella: …at least you want me for more than because I’m hot or something.

Arya: Well, I mean, you are really hot…but it was more important that you’re the only person I know who’d condone revenge sex.

Arya: Well, I mean, you are really hot…but it was more important that you’re the only person I know who’d condone revenge sex.

summary:
sansa: “What happens if you put a werewolf on the moon” is a great question. Probably the best question ever.
Bran: he’d explode...
body:
sansa: “What happens if you put a werewolf on the moon” is a great question. Probably the best question ever.

Bran: he’d explode and die because there’s no oxygen on the moon.

arya: We never said we’d send him up without a suit, you absolute monster.

blog.name: asimplylucia
blog.title: Work Always Without Applause
blog.description: History nerd, fanfic writer, film noir lover.

title: Six Sentence Sunday
body:
Fall is definitely here (in my neck of the woods, anyway) and it’s time to share a few lines from my next SanSan fic:

You would have thought she was talking about some other girl she didn’t know and didn’t care about. She gave me the weirdest kind of smile, a bitter smile that said how proud of herself she was because of my dumbfounded look and of my clenched fist. You didn’t expect this from the little bird, did you? she seemed to say. All of a sudden her smile vanished and her delicate features hardened. Sansa shifted, disappeared behind the bed, exploring another part of the bedroom, before raising to her full height.

“It was under the chest of drawers!” she announced, almost sounding triumphant.

Brandishing her notebook, she moved past me close enough to let me breathe her perfume and to notice her flushed cheeks.

reblog.comment:

Brandishing her notebook, she moved past me close enough to let me breathe her perfume and to notice her flushed cheeks.

trail.content_raw:
Fall is definitely here (in my neck of the woods, anyway) and it’s time to share a few lines from my next SanSan fic:

You would have thought she was talking about some other girl she didn’t know and didn’t care about. She gave me the weirdest kind of smile, a bitter smile that said how proud of herself she was because of my dumbfounded look and of my clenched fist. You didn’t expect this from the little bird, did you? she seemed to say. All of a sudden her smile vanished and her delicate features hardened. Sansa shifted, disappeared behind the bed, exploring another part of the bedroom, before raising to her full height.

“It was under the chest of drawers!” she announced, almost sounding triumphant.

Brandishing her notebook, she moved past me close enough to let me breathe her perfume and to notice her flushed cheeks.

Fall is definitely here (in my neck of the woods, anyway) and it’s time to share a few lines from my next SanSan fic:

You would have thought she was talking about some other girl she didn’t know and didn’t care about. She gave me the weirdest kind of smile, a bitter smile that said how proud of herself she was because of my dumbfounded look and of my clenched fist. You didn’t expect this from the little bird, did you? she seemed to say. All of a sudden her smile vanished and her delicate features hardened. Sansa shifted, disappeared behind the bed, exploring another part of the bedroom, before raising to her full height.

“It was under the chest of drawers!” she announced, almost sounding triumphant.

Brandishing her notebook, she moved past me close enough to let me breathe her perfume and to notice her flushed cheeks.
